comment.author: 69662531@N05
comment._content:
From the Commonwealth War Graves Commission website:

Name:JOSEPH, HERBERT ALLEN
Initials:H A
Nationality:South African
Rank:Second Lieutenant
Regiment/Service:South African Infantry
Unit Text:2nd Regt.
Age:36
Date of Death:08/06/1917
Awards:Mentioned in Despatches
Additional information:Son of Frank Charles Joseph and Edith Joseph, of London.
Casualty Type:Commonwealth War Dead
Grave/Memorial Reference:VI. H. 1.
Cemetery:AUBIGNY COMMUNAL CEMETERY EXTENSION

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
The date of 8 June 1917 and proximity of his grave to the locations of 24th, 30th and 42nd Casualty Clearing Stations suggest that 2Lt Joseph was wounded in the initial assault on Messines Ridge on 7 June 1917.   However the 9th (Scottish) Division, known amongst the troops as the 'Jocks and Springboks' after 1 South African Brigade joined the Division in April 1916, was not committed to this attack.

Survivors of the 3rd South African Infantry Regiment were placed in 2nd South African Infantry Regiment after the Battle for Delville Wood in July 1916.//

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: FreeBMD JOSEPH Herbert Allenbirth reg 2nd qr 1881 Pancras 1b33 Photo of gravestone Grave VI.H.1www.delvillewood.com/cemeteries/joseph.htm

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content: Two months old at the time of the 1881 census he was born on 23rd Jan 1881 at 132 Gower Street, St Pancras (according to his baptism record) and had 5 older siblings aged between 1-6. His father, Frank Charles Joseph, was a 31yr old Clerk Custodian at University Hospital (the baptism record description is House Steward University College Hospital). By 1891 there were a further 2 siblings and the family employed a Servant and a Housekeeper. They were still living at 132 Gower Street and Mr Joseph still employed at the hospital. A family tree on www.ancestry.co.uk shows that Mr Joseph died in 1894. In 1901 his widow and 5 of their children were living at 5 Janson Road, Forest Gate, West Ham, Essex but Herbert was not amongst them. By 1911 she and 2 of her daughters were at Cliftondale, 4 Lower Villas, Cowslip Rd, South Woodford, Essex.
